properties.description: On Wednesday, February 27, 2002, 31 individuals set ablaze the S-6 coach of the Sabarmati Express as it was returning from Ayodhya to Ahmedabad.
On Thursday, April 11, 2002, a fuel tanker blew up outside of a synagogue.
On Tuesday, May 14, 2002, militants fired on a passenger bus. After attacking the bus, the militants entered a military housing complex and began killing soldiers and military dependents.
On Tuesday, September 24, 2002, assailants entered the Akshardham temple and began attacking civilians with gunfire and grenades.

On Wednesday, October 23, 2002, a group of Chechen rebels, including Black Widows, took hostages at the Nord-Ost Theater in the Dubrovska suburb of Moscow. The rebels called for the expulsion of Russians from Chechnya.

properties.terrorist group connected to attack: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
properties.description: On Monday, May 12, 2003, militants attacked the Al Hamra, Jadawal, and Vinnell compounds. The assailants set off their bombs at two of the compounds, while at the third compound, a car bomb was detonated outside of the gate.
On Friday, May 16, 2003, militants detonated five bombs, targeting civilians in bars, hotels, and restaurants including a Jewish center and Spanish social club.
On Friday, August 1, 2003, a Vehicle loaded with explosives, driven by a suicide bomber, exploded in a military hospital.

On Monday, August 25, 2003, two bombs, planted in taxis, exploded within minutes of each other during lunchtime. One of the bombs exploded at the Gateway of India in a taxi parked outside of the Taj Mahal Hotel. The second bomb, which caused even more casualties than the first, exploded in a busy jewelry market near the Mumba Devi temple.
On Monday, October 13, 2003, militants attacked people eating and drinking at open-air bars in the town's market.
On Sunday, November 9, 2003, militants attacked civilians during a rampage in the Lira district.
On Saturday, November 15, 2003, two car bombs exploded outside of synagogues.

properties.terrorist group connected to attack: Al Qaeda (Afghanistan), Islamist Great Eastern Raiders Front (IBDA-C)
properties.description: On Thursday, November 20, 2003, truck bombs exploded at the British Consulate and HSBC bank.
On Wednesday, February 4, 2004, militants attacked civilians at a refugee camp.
On Friday, February 6, 2004, a bomb exploded and tore apart a train car in the Moscow metro during morning rush hour as the train was traveling from Paveletskaya station to Avtozavodskaya station.
On Saturday, February 21, 2004, rebels attacked the Barloonyo refugee camp, which is about 25 km from Lira.

properties.terrorist group connected to attack: Unified Communist Party Of Nepal (Maoist) - Suspected
properties.attacked: Financial Building, Government (Building, Vehicle, Personnel), Utility
properties.description: On Wednesday, March 3, 2004, militants attacked various sites in Bhojpur.
On Thursday, March 11, 2004, bombs concealed in backpacks were detonated on four commuter trains. The bombs were detonated using mobile phones.
On Wednesday, March 24, 2004, militants attacked several villages.
On Wednesday, April 7, 2004, militants attacked policemen when they set off five landmines in the Saranda forest area.
On Friday, May 7, 2004, a suicide bomber detonated explosives in the Shiite Hyderi mosque.

properties.terrorist group connected to attack: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
properties.description: On Saturday, May 29, 2004, gunmen attacked oil company compounds and then took hostages at the Oasis residential building.
On Monday, May 31, 2004, a bomb was detonated inside of the Ali Raza mosque.

properties.terrorist group connected to attack: Unified Communist Party Of Nepal (Maoist) - Suspected
properties.description: On Monday, June 14, 2004, a landmine exploded when two police trucks passed by and then militants began shooting at the officers.
On Tuesday, August 24, 2004, two female suicide bombers detonated explosives on planes. One of the planes was headed for Sochi, while the second plane was headed for Volgograd.

properties.terrorist group connected to attack: Riyadus Salihin Reconnaissance and Sabotage Battalion of Chechen Martyrs
properties.description: On Wednesday, September 1, 2004, gunmen took over 1,000 hostages, mainly children, at a school in Beslan. Most of the deaths took place at the end of the three-day siege after an explosion in the school gym.
On Friday, October 1, 2004, a suicide bomber detonated explosives in the Zainabia mosque.

properties.terrorist group connected to attack: Tawhid Wal Jihad / Unification and Holy War
properties.description: On Thursday, October 7, 2004, a truck loaded with explosives rammed into the lobby of a hotel. Shortly after, a suicide bomber detonated explosives near the swimming pool of the hotel.
On Friday, October 8, 2004, a bomb went off in the middle of a rally at Rashidabad Square.
On Thursday, December 23, 2004, gunfire opened fire on a bus.
On Monday, February 14, 2005, the Prime Minister of Lebanon, Rafik Hariri, was assassinated when a car bomb hit his motorcade.
On Saturday, March 19, 2005, a bomb was detonated while a crowd of pilgrims ate their evening meal near a Muslim shrine.
On Friday, May 27, 2005, a suicide bomber blew himself up near the stage at a shrine.
On Tuesday, May 31, 2005, militants attacked civilians and set fire to their huts in Duekoue, which is west of Issia.
On Monday, June 6, 2005, a bomb exploded on a crowded passenger bus.
On Thursday, July 7, 2005, bombs were detonated targeting tube trains at Aldgate, Edgware Road and Russell Square, and a double deck bus in Tavistock Square.

On Saturday, July 23, 2005, a bomb exploded in the Old Market area of Sharm al-Sheikh. The explosion was followed by a bomber ramming his car into the Ghazala Gardens Hotel, and a bomb exploding in a car park near the Moevenpick Hotel and popular nightlife spots.

properties.terrorist group connected to attack: Communist Party of India (Maoist) / Naxalites - Suspected
properties.description: On Saturday, September 3, 2005, militants detonated a landmine near a vehicle carrying police officers.
On Monday, September 26, 2005, the village of Modoyna was attacked by militants.
On Saturday, October 29, 2005, bombs exploded in Sarojini Nagar, Paharganj and Kalkaji, including one in a bag aboard a DTC bus.

On Wednesday, November 9, 2005, three bombs exploded nearly simultaneously through three hotels in Amman. One bomb exploded in the lobby of the Grand Hyatt Hotel, another hit a wedding party at the Radisson SAS Hotel, and third exploded at the Days Inn Hotel.

properties.attacked: Government (Building, Vehicle, Personnel), Military (Building, Vehicle, Personnel)
properties.description: On Tuesday, January 31, 2006, militants attacked several government and military facilities.
On Tuesday, February 28, 2006, militants set off a landmine under a truck.
On Thursday, March 16, 2006, militants opened fire on the governor of Zahedan, his deputies, and 21 of his companions.
On Tuesday, April 11, 2006, a bomb exploded at a ceremony to mark the anniversary of the Prophet Mohammad's birth.
On Monday, May 1, 2006, militants gunned down 22 Hindus after dragging them out of their houses.

properties.terrorist group connected to attack: Lashkar-e-Tayyiba (LeT), Students Islamic Movement of India (SIMI)
properties.description: On Tuesday, July 11, 2006, seven bombs were packed into pressure cookers with timers attached. The bombs exploded on suburban trains and stations in Mumbai between 6:24 p.m. and 6:35 p.m.
On Friday, September 8, 2006, three bombs went off inside a cemetery and a fourth in the central part of the city.
On Saturday, January 6, 2007, militants shot brick-kiln workers and milkmen.
On Friday, January 19, 2007, militants attacked a community.
On Sunday, February 18, 2007, two firebombs went off on the Samjhauta Express. Three unexploded suitcase-bombs were found on the train during the investigation that followed.
On Thursday, March 15, 2007, assailants planted landmines and bombs near a paramilitary barracks and then began firing upon the barracks with guns and rockets.
On Saturday, March 31, 2007, attackers encircled two villages and opened fire.
On Saturday, April 7, 2007, a bomb exploded on a bus parked at a bus stand.
On Tuesday, April 24, 2007, gunmen raided a Chinese-run oil field.
On Saturday, April 28, 2007, a suicide bomber detonated explosives at a public rally of Federal Interior Minister Aftab Ahmed Khan Sherpao.

On Saturday, August 25, 2007, three bombs exploded nearly simultaneously. One bomb exploded at the Gokul Chat shop, while two others detonated at the Lumbini amusement park during an open-air laser show. During the investigation that followed, three other devices were found around the city, including two in cinemas.

properties.terrorist group connected to attack: Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) - Suspected, Taliban (Afghanistan) - Suspected, Al Qaeda (Afghanistan) - Suspected
properties.description: On Thursday, October 18, 2007, a suicide bomber detonated explosives in the middle of a crowd near the vehicle carrying Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto. A second explosion occurred shortly after the first one.
On Saturday, November 24, 2007, a suicide bomber hit a staff bus while trying to enter the Hamza Camp. A second suicide bomber blew up his car after hitting an Army checkpoint.

properties.attacked: Government (Building, Vehicle, Personnel), Religious (Building, Vehicle, Personnel)
properties.description: On Friday, December 21, 2007, a suicide bomber detonated explosives in a mosque where a former interior minister was offering Muslim Eid festival prayers.
On Thursday, December 27, 2007, an assailant shot Prime Minister Benzair Bhutto in the neck and then a suicide attacker detonated his bomb.
On Monday, December 31, 2007, a mob of men set ablaze a church where villagers had sought refuge from Kenya's post-election violence.
On Thursday, January 10, 2008, a suicide bomber blew himself up outside the High Court in Lahore.
On Saturday, February 9, 2008, a suicide bomber detonated explosives at a Pakistan election rally.
On Tuesday, March 11, 2008, a suicide car bomber targeted the federal police headquarters.
On Tuesday, May 13, 2008, nine bombs, which were a mix of plastic RDX explosive, ammonium nitrate, and ball-bearings, exploded in markets surrounding the Hawa Mahal and its main temple complex.

properties.terrorist group connected to attack: Indian Mujahideen, Students Islamic Movement of India (SIMI)
properties.description: On Saturday, July 26, 2008, seventeen bombs exploded, hitting residential areas, markets, a train station, and a bus.

On Thursday, August 21, 2008, a suicide bomber blew himself up near the main gate of the Pakistan Ordnance Factories. A second suicide bomber detonated explosives near another gate of the establishment.
On Friday, September 12, 2008, authorities found the bodies of 24 people who had been kidnapped earlier in the week in Arcelia and executed. The bodies had been dumped near Mexico City.
On Saturday, September 13, 2008, a series of at least five explosions struck a park and crowded shopping areas.
On Saturday, September 20, 2008, a suicide bomber fired on a security checkpoint and then detonated explosives in his vehicle at the Marriott Hotel.

On Thursday, October 30, 2008, 13 bombs exploded in Assam. Explosions occurred near the Ganeshguri fly over, the Paltan Bazaar, the Fancy Bazaar, and the crowded markets of Kokrajhar, Bongaigaon and Barpeta.

On Wednesday, November 26, 2008, ten gunmen began attacking sites around the city of Mumbai, including the Oberoi, Taj Mahal, and Tower Hotels. The gunmen attacked approximately 10 sites over the course of their three day attack.
On Thursday, February 5, 2009, a bomb exploded at a bus stand near a religious procession.
On Sunday, April 5, 2009, a suicide bomber detonated explosives at the entrance to a crowded Shiite mosque.
On Saturday, April 18, 2009, a suicide bomber drove his vehicle into a military checkpost and detonated his explosives.
On Sunday, July 5, 2009, riots broke out between Han Chinese and Muslim Uighurs.
On Saturday, October 10, 2009, militants attacked an army headquarters and took civilians and military personnel hostage.
On Sunday, October 18, 2009, an attacker detonated a bomb belt as Revolutionary Guard commanders arrived for a meeting with tribal elders in a sports hall.
On Monday, November 2, 2009, a man on a motorbike blew himself up at the National Bank of Pakistan where soldiers and civilians had gathered to collect their monthly salaries and pension payments.
On Tuesday, November 10, 2009, a suicide bomb detonated explosives in a car at a crowded intersection in the Charsadda bazaar.

properties.terrorist group connected to attack: Riyadus Salihin Reconnaissance and Sabotage Battalion of Chechen Martyrs
properties.description: On Friday, November 27, 2009, a bomb, equivalent to 7kg of TNT, exploded and derailed at least three of the 14 carriages of the Nevsky Express.
On Friday, December 4, 2009, gunmen stormed a mosque, detonating bombs and shooting worshippers.
On Monday, December 7, 2009, two suicide bombers detonated explosives within seconds of each other in a crowded market.
On Tuesday, December 15, 2009, a suicide bomber detonated an explosives-laden car in a market.
On Monday, December 28, 2009, a suicide bomber detonated explosives in a Shiite religious procession.
On Monday, February 15, 2010, militants, many of them women, attacked an Eastern Frontier Rifles camp and set fire to the camp before leaving.
On Sunday, March 7, 2010, Muslim militants attacked mostly Christian villages.
On Friday, March 12, 2010, suicide bombers blew themselves up after walking up to Pakistani army vehicles in a bazaar.
On Saturday, March 20, 2010, assailants with axes and machetes attacked several villages in Haut-Mbomou, including Agoumar, Mboki, and Zemio.

On Monday, March 29, 2010, a female suicide bomber (Black Widow) detonated an explosive on a train stopped at the Lubyanka station. About 40 minutes later, another female suicide bomber detonated an explosive in the carriage of a train on the platform at the Park Kultury metro station.
On Monday, May 17, 2010, militants triggered a bomb near a bus carrying civilians and Special Police Officers (SPOs). The attack took place in Chingavaram, which is near Sukma.
On Friday, May 28, 2010, assailants removed a piece of railroad track resulting in the derailment of the Calcutta-Mumbai express train.
On Friday, May 28, 2010, assailants attacked Ahmadiyya places of worship.
On Thursday, July 1, 2010, three suicide bombers detonated explosives at the Data Darbar shrine.
On Sunday, July 11, 2010, bombs targeted World Cup parties when they detonated at a rugby club and Ethiopian restaurant in Kampala.
On Thursday, July 15, 2010, double suicide bombings targeted a Shiite mosque. They were carried out to avenge the execution of the leader of Jundallah.
On Wednesday, September 1, 2010, assailants threw a grenade and two suicide bombers detonated explosives in a Shia procession.
On Thursday, September 9, 2010, gunmen killed a number of people when they stormed into multiple homes in Ciudad Juarez.
On Wednesday, December 15, 2010, a suicide bomber detonated explosives inside a mosque where a funeral was taking place.
On Friday, December 24, 2010, seven bombs were detonated in two areas of Jos.
